owl:Class.rdfs:label: Physical Resource

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Additional information to a process, like work schedule production plans, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Information Object

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class Goal represents the desired outcome of a Function
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Goal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Description of date and time structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system. The temporal reference system is fixed to Gregorian Calendar, and the range of year, month, day properties restricted to corresponding XML Schema types xsd:gYear, xsd:gMonth and xsd:gDay, respectively.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Date-Time description
owl:Class.skos:definition: Description of date and time structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system. The temporal reference system is fixed to Gregorian Calendar, and the range of year, month, day properties restricted to corresponding XML Schema types xsd:gYear, xsd:gMonth and xsd:gDay, respectively.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: DateTimeInterval is a subclass of ProperInterval, defined using the multi-element DateTimeDescription.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Date-time interval
owl:Class.skos:definition: DateTimeInterval is a subclass of ProperInterval, defined using the multi-element DateTimeDescription.
owl:Class.skos:note: :DateTimeInterval can only be used for an interval whose limits coincide with a date-time element aligned to the calendar and timezone indicated. For example, while both have a duration of one day, the 24-hour interval beginning at midnight at the beginning of 8 May in Central Europe can be expressed as a :DateTimeInterval, but the 24-hour interval starting at 1:30pm cannot.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The day of week
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Day of week
owl:Class.skos:changeNote:
Remove enumeration from definition, in order to allow other days to be used when required in other calendars. NOTE: existing days are still present as members of the class, but the class membership is now open.
In the original OWL-Time the following constraint appeared: owl:oneOf ( time:Monday time:Tuesday time:Wednesday time:Thursday time:Friday time:Saturday time:Sunday ) ;
owl:Class.skos:definition: The day of week
owl:Class.skos:note: Membership of the class :DayOfWeek is open, to allow for alternative week lengths and different day names.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Duration of a temporal extent expressed as a number scaled by a temporal unit
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time duration
owl:Class.skos:definition: Duration of a temporal extent expressed as a number scaled by a temporal unit
owl:Class.skos:note: Alternative to time:DurationDescription to support description of a temporal duration other than using a calendar/clock system.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Description of temporal extent structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system. The temporal reference system is fixed to Gregorian Calendar, and the range of each of the numeric properties is restricted to xsd:decimal
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Duration description
owl:Class.skos:definition: Description of temporal extent structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system. The temporal reference system is fixed to Gregorian Calendar, and the range of each of the numeric properties is restricted to xsd:decimal
owl:Class.skos:note: In the Gregorian calendar the length of the month is not fixed. Therefore, a value like "2.5 months" cannot be exactly compared with a similar duration expressed in terms of weeks or days.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Description of date and time structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Generalized date-time description
owl:Class.skos:definition: Description of date and time structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system
owl:Class.skos:note: Some combinations of properties are redundant - for example, within a specified :year if :dayOfYear is provided then :day and :month can be computed, and vice versa. Individual values should be consistent with each other and the calendar, indicated through the value of the :hasTRS property.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Description of temporal extent structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Generalized duration description
owl:Class.skos:definition: Description of temporal extent structured with separate values for the various elements of a calendar-clock system.
owl:Class.skos:note: The extent of a time duration expressed as a GeneralDurationDescription depends on the Temporal Reference System. In some calendars the length of the week or month is not constant within the year. Therefore, a value like "2.5 months" may not necessarily be exactly compared with a similar duration expressed in terms of weeks or days. When non-earth-based calendars are considered even more care must be taken in comparing durations.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal entity with zero extent or duration
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time instant
owl:Class.skos:definition: A temporal entity with zero extent or duration

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal entity with an extent or duration
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time interval
owl:Class.skos:definition: A temporal entity with an extent or duration

owl:Class.rdfs:label: January
owl:Class.skos:historyNote: This class was present in the 2006 version of OWL-Time. It was presented as an example of how DateTimeDescription could be specialized, but does not belong in the revised ontology.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The month of the year
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Month of year
owl:Class.skos:definition: The month of the year
owl:Class.skos:editorialNote: Feature at risk - added in 2017 revision, and not yet widely used.
owl:Class.skos:note: Membership of the class :MonthOfYear is open, to allow for alternative annual calendars and different month names.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal entity with non-zero extent or duration, i.e. for which the value of the beginning and end are different
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Proper interval
owl:Class.skos:definition: A temporal entity with non-zero extent or duration, i.e. for which the value of the beginning and end are different

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A temporal reference system, such as a temporal coordinate system (with an origin, direction, and scale), a calendar-clock combination, or a (possibly hierarchical) ordinal system.
This is a stub class, representing the set of all temporal reference systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temporal Reference System
owl:Class.skos:definition:
A temporal reference system, such as a temporal coordinate system (with an origin, direction, and scale), a calendar-clock combination, or a (possibly hierarchical) ordinal system.
This is a stub class, representing the set of all temporal reference systems.
owl:Class.skos:note: A taxonomy of temporal reference systems is provided in ISO 19108:2002 [ISO19108], including (a) calendar + clock systems; (b) temporal coordinate systems (i.e. numeric offset from an epoch); (c) temporal ordinal reference systems (i.e. ordered sequence of named intervals, not necessarily of equal duration).

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Time extent; duration of a time interval separate from its particular start position
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temporal duration
owl:Class.skos:definition: Time extent; duration of a time interval separate from its particular start position

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal interval or instant.
A temporal interval or instant.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temporal entity
Temporal entity
owl:Class.skos:definition: A temporal interval or instant.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A position on a time-line
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temporal position
owl:Class.skos:definition: A position on a time-line

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A standard duration, which provides a scale factor for a time extent, or the granularity or precision for a time position.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temporal unit
owl:Class.skos:changeNote:
Remove enumeration from definition, in order to allow other units to be used when required in other coordinate systems. NOTE: existing units are still present as members of the class, but the class membership is now open.
In the original OWL-Time the following constraint appeared: owl:oneOf ( time:unitSecond time:unitMinute time:unitHour time:unitDay time:unitWeek time:unitMonth time:unitYear ) ;
owl:Class.skos:definition: A standard duration, which provides a scale factor for a time extent, or the granularity or precision for a time position.
owl:Class.skos:note: Membership of the class TemporalUnit is open, to allow for other temporal units used in some technical applications (e.g. millions of years, Baha'i month).

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal position described using either a (nominal) value from an ordinal reference system, or a (numeric) value in a temporal coordinate system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time position
owl:Class.skos:definition: A temporal position described using either a (nominal) value from an ordinal reference system, or a (numeric) value in a temporal coordinate system.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Time Zone specifies the amount by which the local time is offset from UTC. A time zone is usually denoted geographically (e.g. Australian Eastern Daylight Time), with a constant value in a given region. The region where it applies and the offset from UTC are specified by a locally recognised governing authority.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time Zone
owl:Class.skos:definition: A Time Zone specifies the amount by which the local time is offset from UTC. A time zone is usually denoted geographically (e.g. Australian Eastern Daylight Time), with a constant value in a given region. The region where it applies and the offset from UTC are specified by a locally recognised governing authority.
owl:Class.skos:historyNote:
In the original 2006 version of OWL-Time, the TimeZone class, with several properties corresponding to a specific model of time-zones, was defined in a separate namespace "http://www.w3.org/2006/timezone#".
In the current version a class with same local name is put into the main OWL-Time namespace, removing the dependency on the external namespace.
An alignment axiom tzont:TimeZone rdfs:subClassOf time:TimeZone . allows data encoded according to the previous version to be consistent with the updated ontology.
owl:Class.skos:note:
A designated timezone is associated with a geographic region. However, for a particular region the offset from UTC often varies seasonally, and the dates of the changes may vary from year to year. The timezone designation usually changes for the different seasons (e.g. Australian Eastern Standard Time vs. Australian Eastern Daylight Time). Furthermore, the offset for a timezone may change over longer timescales, though its designation might not.
Detailed guidance about working with time zones is given in http://www.w3.org/TR/timezone/ .

An ontology for time zone descriptions was described in [owl-time-20060927] and provided as RDF in a separate namespace tzont:. However, that ontology was incomplete in scope, and the example datasets were selective. Furthermore, since the use of a class from an external ontology as the range of an ObjectProperty in OWL-Time creates a dependency, reference to the time zone class has been replaced with the 'stub' class in the normative part of this version of OWL-Time.
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: In this implementation TimeZone has no properties defined. It should be thought of as an 'abstract' superclass of all specific timezone implementations.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Year duration
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Year
owl:Class.skos:definition: Year duration
owl:Class.skos:historyNote:
Year was proposed in the 2006 version of OWL-Time as an example of how DurationDescription could be specialized to allow for a duration to be restricted to a number of years.
It is deprecated in this edition of OWL-Time.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Observation Collection has at least one member, and may have one of any of the other seven properties mentioned in restrictions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observation Collection

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Represents a collection of people organized together into a community or other social, commercial or political structure. The group has some common purpose or reason for existence which goes beyond the set of people belonging to it and can act as an Agent. Organizations are often decomposed into hierarchical structures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Organization

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Organization such as a department or support unit which is part of some larger Organization and only has full recognition within the context of that Organization. In particular the unit would not be regarded as a legal entity in its own right.
Usage: Units can be large and complex containing other Units.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Organizational Unit
OrganizationalUnit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An actuatable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Actuatable Property
owl:Class.skos:definition: An actuatable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.
owl:Class.skos:example: A window actuator acts by changing the state between a frame and a window. The ability of the window to be opened and closed is its ActuatableProperty.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Actuation carries out an (Actuation) Procedure to change the state of the world using an Actuator.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Actuation
owl:Class.skos:definition: An Actuation carries out an (Actuation) Procedure to change the state of the world using an Actuator.
owl:Class.skos:example: The activity of automatically closing a window if the temperature in a room drops below 20 degree Celsius. The activity is the Actuation and the device that closes the window is the Actuator. The Procedure is the rule, plan, or specification that defines the conditions that triggers the Actuation, here a drop in temperature.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A device that is used by, or implements, an (Actuation) Procedure that changes the state of the world.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Actuator
owl:Class.skos:definition: A device that is used by, or implements, an (Actuation) Procedure that changes the state of the world.
owl:Class.skos:example: A window actuator for automatic window control, i.e., opening or closing the window.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Feature Of Interest
owl:Class.skos:definition: The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.
owl:Class.skos:example: When measuring the height of a tree, the height is the observed ObservableProperty, 20m may be the Result of the Observation, and the tree is the FeatureOfInterest. A window is a FeatureOfInterest for an automatic window control Actuator.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An observable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observable Property
owl:Class.skos:definition: An observable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.
owl:Class.skos:example: The height of a tree, the depth of a water body, or the temperature of a surface are examples of observable properties, while the value of a classic car is not (directly) observable but asserted.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to a Sensor to describe what made the Observation and how; links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that property was associated with.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to a Sensor to describe what made the Observation and how; links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that property was associated with.
owl:Class.skos:example: The activity of estimating the intensity of an Earthquake using the Mercalli intensity scale is an Observation as is measuring the moment magnitude, i.e., the energy released by said earthquake.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly Sensors, Actuators, Samplers, and other Platforms.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Platform
owl:Class.skos:definition: A Platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly Sensors, Actuators, Samplers, and other Platforms.
owl:Class.skos:example: A post, buoy, vehicle, ship, aircraft, satellite, cell-phone, human or animal may act as platforms for (technical or biological) sensors or actuators.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A workflow, protocol, plan, algorithm, or computational method specifying how to make an Observation, create a Sample, or make a change to the state of the world (via an Actuator). A Procedure is re-usable, and might be involved in many Observations, Samplings, or Actuations. It explains the steps to be carried out to arrive at reproducible results.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Procedure
owl:Class.skos:definition: A workflow, protocol, plan, algorithm, or computational method specifying how to make an Observation, create a Sample, or make a change to the state of the world (via an Actuator). A Procedure is re-usable, and might be involved in many Observations, Samplings, or Actuations. It explains the steps to be carried out to arrive at reproducible results.
owl:Class.skos:example: The measured wind speed differs depending on the height of the sensor above the surface, e.g., due to friction. Consequently, procedures for measuring wind speed define a standard height for anemometers above ground, typically 10m for meteorological measures and 2m in Agrometeorology. This definition of height, sensor placement, and so forth are defined by the Procedure.
owl:Class.skos:note: Many observations may be created via the same Procedure, the same way as many tables are assembled using the same instructions (as information objects, not their concrete realization).

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Result
owl:Class.skos:definition: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.
owl:Class.skos:example: The value 20 as the height of a certain tree together with the unit, e.g., Meter.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Sample is the result from an act of Sampling.
Feature which is intended to be representative of a FeatureOfInterest on which Observations may be made.
Physical samples are sometimes known as 'specimens'.

Samples are artifacts of an observational strategy, and have no significant function outside of their role in the observation process. The characteristics of the samples themselves are of little interest, except perhaps to the manager of a sampling campaign.
A Sample is intended to sample some FatureOfInterest, so there is an expectation of at least one isSampleOf property. However, in some cases the identity, and even the exact type, of the sampled feature may not be known when observations are made using the sampling features.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sample
owl:Class.skos:definition: Feature which is intended to be representative of a FeatureOfInterest on which Observations may be made.
owl:Class.skos:example: A 'station' is essentially an identifiable locality where a sensor system or Procedure may be deployed and an observation made. In the context of the observation model, it connotes the 'world in the vicinity of the station', so the observed properties relate to the physical medium at the station, and not to any physical artifact such as a mooring, buoy, benchmark, monument, well, etc.

A statistical sample is often designed to be characteristic of an entire population, so that observations can be made regarding the sample that provide a good estimate of the properties of the population.
owl:Class.skos:note: A transient sample, such as a ships-track or flight-line, might be identified and described, but is unlikely to be revisited exactly.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A device that is used by, or implements, a Sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sampler
owl:Class.skos:definition: A device that is used by, or implements, a Sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.
owl:Class.skos:example: A ball mill, diamond drill, hammer, hypodermic syringe and needle, image Sensor or a soil auger can all act as sampling devices (i.e., be Samplers). However, sometimes the distinction between the Sampler and the Sensor is not evident, as they are packaged as a unit. A Sampler need not be a physical device.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An act of Sampling carries out a sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sampling
owl:Class.skos:definition: An act of Sampling carries out a sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.
owl:Class.skos:example: Crushing a rock sample in a ball mill.
Digging a pit through a soil sequence.
Dividing a field site into quadrants.
Drawing blood from a patient.
Drilling an observation well.
Establishing a station for environmental monitoring.
Registering an image of the landscape.
Selecting a subset of a population.
Sieving a powder to separate the subset finer than 100-mesh.
Splitting a piece of drill-core to create two new samples.
Taking a diamond-drill core from a rock outcrop.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensor
owl:Class.skos:definition: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.
owl:Class.skos:example: Accelerometers, gyroscopes, barometers, magnetometers, and so forth are Sensors that are typically mounted on a modern smart phone (which acts as Platform). Other examples of sensors include the human eyes.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Nature of a relationship (between samples) - Members of this class indicate the nature of a relationship between two samples.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Relationship Nature

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Members of this class represent a relationship between a sample and another.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sample Relationship

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Used to specify ranges for qualities that act as Condition on a Systems' operation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Condition
owl:Class.skos:example: For example, wind speed of 10-60m/s may be used as the Condition on a SystemProperty, for example, to state that a sensor has a particular Accuracy under that Condition.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Describes the Deployment of one or more Systems for a particular purpose. Deployment may be done on a Platform.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Deployment
owl:Class.skos:definition: Describes the Deployment of one or more Systems for a particular purpose. Deployment may be done on a Platform.
owl:Class.skos:example: For example, a temperature Sensor deployed on a wall, or a whole network of Sensors deployed for an Observation campaign.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any information that is provided to a Procedure for its use.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Input
owl:Class.skos:definition: Any information that is provided to a Procedure for its use.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any information that is reported from a Procedure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Output
owl:Class.skos:definition: Any information that is reported from a Procedure.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specifies the number of sensor measurements used internally to generate one sensor output result. (Oversampling rate = OSR)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Oversampling Rate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A quality of an entity. An aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Property
owl:Class.skos:definition: A quality of an entity. An aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An event in the real world that 'triggers' the Sensor. The properties associated to the Stimulus may be different to the eventual observed ObservableProperty. It is the event, not the object, that triggers the Sensor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Stimulus
owl:Class.skos:definition: An event in the real world that 'triggers' the Sensor. The properties associated to the Stimulus may be different to the eventual observed ObservableProperty. It is the event, not the object, that triggers the Sensor.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implement Procedures. A System may have components, its subsystems, which are other systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System
owl:Class.skos:definition: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implement Procedures. A System may have components, its subsystems, which are other systems.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The closeness of agreement between the Result of an Observation (resp. The command of an Actuation) and the true value of the observed ObservableProperty (resp. Of the acted on ActuableProperty) under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Accuracy

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The range of property values that can be the Result of an Actuation under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Actuation Range

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Total useful life of a System's battery in the specified Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Battery Lifetime

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An observed value for which the probability of falsely claiming the absence of a component in a material is beta, given a probability alpha of falsely claiming its presence.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Detection Limit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As a Sensor Property: a continuous or incremental change in the reported values of Observations over time for an unchanging Property under the defined Conditions. As an Actuator Property: a continuous or incremental change in the true value of the acted on ActuableProperty over time for an unchanging command under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Drift

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The smallest possible time between one Observation, Actuation, or Sampling and the next, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Frequency

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The time between a command for an Observation and the Sensor providing a Result, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Latency

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Schedule of maintenance for a System in the specified Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Maintenance Schdule

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The set of values that the Sensor can return as the Result of an Observation under the defined Conditions with the defined system properties.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Measurement Range

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Power range in which System is expected to operate in the specified.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Operating Power Range

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An identifiable characteristic that represents how the System operates under the specified Conditions. May describe power ranges, power sources, standard configurations, attachments and the like.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Operating Property

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: "Describes normal OperatingProperties of a System under some specified Conditions. For example, to the power requirement or maintenance schedule of a System under a specified temperature range. In the absence of OperatingProperties, it simply describes the Conditions in which a System is expected to operate."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Operating Range

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As a sensor capability: The closeness of agreement between replicate Observations on an unchanged or similar quality value: i.e., a measure of a Sensor's ability to consistently reproduce an Observation, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Precision

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As an actuator capability: The closeness of agreement between replicate Actuations for an unchanged or similar command: i.e., a measure of an Actuator's ability to consistently reproduce an Actuations, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Resolution

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As a Sensor Property: the time between a (step) change in the value of an observed ObservableProperty and a Sensor (possibly with specified error) 'settling' on an observed value, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Response Time

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As an Actuator Property: the time between a (step) change in the command of an Actuator and the 'settling' of the value of the acted on ActuatableProperty, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Selectivity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As a Sensor Property: Sensitivity is the quotient of the change in a Result of Observations and the corresponding change in a value of an ObservableProperty being observed, under the defined Conditions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensitivity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An identifiable characteristic that represents the extent of the System's useful life under the specified Conditions. May describe for example total battery life or number of recharges, or, for Sensors that are used only a fixed number of times, the number of Observations that can be made before the sensing capability is depleted.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Survival Property

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: "Describes SurvivalProperties of a System under some specified Conditions. For example, the lifetime of a System under a specified temperature range. In the absence of SurvivalProperties, simply describes the Conditions a System can be exposed to without damage. For example, the temperature range a System can withstand before being considered damaged."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Survival Range

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Describes normal measurement, actuation, sampling properties such as accuracy, range, precision, etc. Of a System under some specified Conditions such as temperature range. The capabilities specified here are those that affect the primary purpose of the System, while those in OperatingRange represent the system's normal operating environment, including Conditions that don't affect the Observations or the Actuations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Capability

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The System continues to operate as defined using SystemCapability. If, however, the SurvivalRange is violated, the System is 'damaged' and SystemCapability specifications may no longer hold.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Lifetime

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An identifiable and observable characteristic that represents the system's ability to operate its primary purpose: a sensor to make Observations, an Actuator to make Actuations, or a Sampler to make Sampling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Property

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Application services – they are application specific and are implemented by application systems along with functionalities (to match requirements of an application)

Software system, that belongs to the "standard" components offered by Arrowhead framework. Arrowhead core systems can occur once in each Arrowhead Local Cloud. Arriwhead Core Systems can be distinguished in Arrowhead Mandatory Core Systems and Automation supporting systems. Mandatory core systems must exist in each Arrowhead Local Cloud, Automation supporting systems can occur in an Arrowhead Local Cloud.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Arrowhead Core Component
Arrowhead Core System

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Class of all Interface Design Descriptions (IDDs) of mandatory Arrowwhead core services. While the class AH_mandatory_core_service contains the mandatory core services only as instances, this class contains classes of the IDDs of each single mandatory core service as subclasses (not only as instances). Since each AH Local Cloud runs one instance of each mandatory core service, each of these services has to be documented by an AH service documentation, i.e. at least by a SD and a IDD. So the IDD is an individual document for each mandatory core service in each single Local Cloud. Hence, all IDDs of a certain mandatory core service will be individuals of the corresponding IDD class.

Document belonging to the documentation of an Arrowhead Service. There are four types of documents for Arrowhead service documentations: - Service Description - Interface Design Description - Communication Profile - Semantic Profile. The central documents are IDDs. They document the implementation of a certain service based on a certain communication technology (communication, encoding, data format) and a certain information model. The Service Description contains a more general description of the service, without the link to a specific communication technology or information model. Communication Profiles and Semantic Profiles are optional documents for a service documentation. They can be seen as modules of an IDD, since they can describe the communication technolopgy and the information model of a service implementation as external documents. If they exist, the IDD refers to them instead of declaring these contents by themselfes. That is, CP and SP are useful if different service implementations use the same CP and SP - then their IDDs can refer to one and the same CP or SP document.
corresponds to a part of OSI layer 5
Communications technology, also known as information technology, refers to all equipment and programs that are used to process and communicate information.

A constrained device is a device in the sense of an service-oriented architecture that is restricted in terms of processing capabilities (speed, complexity of operations), memory and power supply. The concept constrained device was introduced in the context of the Internet of Things (IoT) and refers for example to sensor devices, location devices, switches etc. which are connected by low-power wireless communication technologies like BLE, ZigBee, Z-Wave etc., have a battery on board that should last for two to three years and which are (very) small in physical size.
Data format in information technology may refer to: Data type, constraint placed upon the interpretation of data in a type system.
corresponds to OSI layer 1 and 2 technologies, like Ethernet, WLAN (802.11), WPAN (802.15.4), EtherCAT, ProfiNet, ...
A data model is an abstract model that organizes elements of data and standardizes how they relate to one another and to the properties of real-world entities.

A device in the context of Arrowhead framework is a piece of equipment, machine, hardware, etc. with computational, memory, and communication capabilities which hosts one or several Arrowhead Framework systems. (Source: Arrowhead)

A device in the context of Service-oriented architectures (that is, in the context of Information Technology (IT) and Automation / Operations Technology (OT)) is an technical artefact that fulfills the basic definition of a "computer". That is, a device must be able to host (run) software systems. For this, it needs at least a processing unit (processor), a memory and a communication interface, which can be either wired or wireless.
A document that documents something

The end-to-end principle is a design framework in computer networking. In networks designed according to this principle, application-specific features reside in the communicating end nodes of the network, rather than in intermediary nodes, such as gateways and routers, that exist to establish the network.
A gateway is a piece of networking hardware used in telecommunications for telecommunications networks that allows data to flow from one discrete network to another.
A category of devices which's purpose is to illuminate

Industrial PCs are primarily used for process control and/or data acquisition. In some cases, an industrial PC is simply used as a front-end to another control computer in a distributed processing environment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IPC

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An information model in software engineering is a representation of concepts and the relationships, constraints, rules, and operations to specify data semantics for a chosen domain of discourse. Typically it specifies relations between kinds of things, but may also include relations with individual things.
A local area network is a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area
Method of a service: method that is provided by a service within a SoA.
A personal computer is a multi-purpose computer whose size, capabilities, and price make it feasible for individual use.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: PC

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: corresponds to OSI layer 3, e.g. IPv4 or IPv6
A programmable logic controller is an industrial digital computer which has been ruggedized and adapted for the control of manufacturing processes
owl:Class.rdfs:label: PLC
SPS

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Raspberry Pi is a series of small single-board computers developed in the United Kingdom by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to put the power of computing and digital making into the hands of people all over the world.
A category of devices which's purpose is to sense

In the context of the Arrowhead Framework a Service is the information exchanged from a providing system to a consuming system. • is based on a number of service orientation principles derived from high level objectives and properties of the Arrowhead framework • can be realized by an arbitrary number of service producers and service consumers • a system can consume a number of services, process and provide other services to fulfil a more complex task • can only be provided by technical systems • can support operational activities within business processes • can support non-functional requirements, such as real-time • can have stakeholders, with an interest in business benefit, in one or more specific area of interest • can have an appointed stakeholder, responsible for the governance of the Service (definition, development). (Source: Arrowhead Framework Definitions V2.4 & Arrowhead Device Registry Presentation)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Service

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Service-oriented architecture is a style of software design where services are provided to the other components by application components, through a communication protocol over a network.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SoA

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Service documentation is any communicable material that is used to describe, explain or instruct regarding some attributes of a service
A smartphone is a mobile device that combines cellular and mobile computing functions into one unit.
System software is software designed to provide a platform for other software.
A switch is a device in a computer network that connects other devices together.

System of systems is a collection of task-oriented or dedicated systems that pool their resources and capabilities together to create a new, more complex system which offers more functionality and performance than simply the sum of the constituent systems.

Description of an Arrowhead compliant software system in terms of the Web Application Description Language WADL. The Web Application Description Language (WADL) is a machine-readable XML description of HTTP-based web services. WADL models the resources provided by a service and the relationships between them. WADL is intended to simplify the reuse of web services that are based on the existing HTTP architecture of the Web. It is platform and language independent and aims to promote reuse of applications beyond the basic use in a web browser. WADL is the REST equivalent of SOAP's Web Services Description Language (WSDL), which can also be used to describe REST web services. Sources: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Application_Description_Language Sun Microsystems (31 August 2009). "Web Application Description Language: W3C Member Submission 31 August 2009". World Wide Web Consortium. Retrieved 12 August 2012. World Wide Web Consortium (14 October 2009). "Team Comment on the "Web Application Description Language" Submission". World Wide Web Consortium. Retrieved 12 August 2012. Lawrence Mandel (29 May 2008). "Describe REST Web services with WSDL 2.0: A how-to guide". IBM. Retrieved 12 August 2012.
System documentation is any communicable material that is used to describe, explain or instruct regarding some attributes of a system
A tablet computer, commonly shortened to tablet, is a mobile device, typically with a mobile operating system and touchscreen display
corresponds to OSI layers 6 and 7
Is a private non-profit organization that oversees the development of voluntary consensus standards for products, services, processes, systems, and personnel in the United States.
Is a private non-profit organization that oversees the development of voluntary consensus standards for products, services, processes, systems, and personnel in the United States.
Is predominant in North America.
B2MML consists of a set of XML schemas written using the World Wide Web Consortium's XML Schema language (XSD) that implement the data models in the ISA-95 standard.
Is a delimited text file that uses a comma to separate values. Each line of the file is a data record.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Comma Separated Values

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is a collection of characters that might be used by multiple languages.
A communications device is any type of hardware capable of transmitting data, instructions, and information between a sending device and a receiving device.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: CommunicationDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A computer is a machine that can be instructed to carry out sequences of arithmetic or logical operations automatically via computer programming.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Computer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Output devices that work in conjunction with sensor input devices and commands from computers in order to control a process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Control Device

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Units of technical data transfer. Shows the different data groupings at the ISO/OSI communication layers, e.g. bits on the physical link layer and packets at the network layer.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Data Transmission Unit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.

The term "Digital Factory" is used in different meanings today and should hence not longer be used. It should be replaced by more specific terms like "Digital Factory Planning system" or "Digital Factory Twin". Originally, Digital Factory referred to software tools for computer-aided planning, design, engineering and simulation of production, manufacturing, or assembly systems. These tools supplemented CAD-based tools for factory layout planning and tools for computer-aided tools for production engineering (work plan preparation, production process planning) and were glued together with them to PLM software suites. As today even CAD-based layout planning and process planning tools are "digital" and refer to the factory, the terms "Digital Factory tool" and "Production Engineering tool" more and more converge. At the same time, automation vendors start to use the concept "Digital Factory" to address online monitoring and control tools for production systems. In this meaning, the term is a synonym for "Digital Factory Twin" or "Digital Twin of a Factory". The important difference between these two meanings is the phase in the life cycle in which the tool is used: Manufacturing Planning / Eingineering is conducted mainly in the first two lifecycle phases in which the product (type, class) is created, designed, and engineered, as well as the corresponding production system. The online monitoring and control is conducted during the third phase, in which the product individuals are produced on the existing production system. Hartwig Baumgaertel, 2018-11-12
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Digital-Factory-System

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is a set of markup declarations that define a document type for an SGML-family markup language (GML, SGML, XML, HTML).
Data Format of EDIFACT messages. Describes e.g. block organization, data field separators etc. Holds for all EDIFACT messages (which are described in DataSemantics class hierarchy).
Is an Electronic Data Interchange format used in Business-to-business transactions. It allows EDIFACT message types to be used by XML systems.
It provides a technical basis for automated commercial "conversations" between two entities, either internal or external.
Beispiel für Feldbus der ersten Generation ist Profibus, Beispiel für Feldbus der zweiten Generation ist ProfiNet.

Ein Feldbus ist ein Bussystem, das in einer Anlage Feldgeräte wie Messfühler (Sensoren) und Stellglieder (Aktoren) zwecks Kommunikation mit einem Automatisierungsgerät verbindet. Wenn mehrere Kommunikationsteilnehmer ihre Nachrichten über dieselbe Leitung senden, dann muss festgelegt sein, wer (Kennung) was (Messwert, Befehl) wann (Initiative) sagt. Hierfür gibt es normierte Protokolle. Die erste Generation der Feldbustechnik wurde in den 1980er Jahren entwickelt, um die bis dahin übliche Parallelverdrahtung binärer Signale sowie die analoge Signalübertragung durch digitale Übertragungstechnik zu ersetzen. Heute sind viele unterschiedliche Feldbussysteme mit unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften am Markt etabliert. Seit 1999 werden Feldbusse in der Norm IEC 61158 (Digital data communication for measurement and control - Fieldbus for use in industrial control systems) sowie durch die Norm IEC 61784 weltweit standardisiert. Die zweite Generation der Feldbustechnik basiert auf Echtzeit-Ethernet (Industrial Ethernet).
Ein Feldbus definiert einen kompletten Protokoll-Stack über die 7 SChichten des OSI-Schichtenmodells. Ggf. werden nicht alle Schichten belegt.

MQTT[1] (Message Queuing Telemetry Transport) is an ISO standard (ISO/IEC PRF 20922)[2] publish-subscribe-based messaging protocol. It works on top of the TCP/IP protocol. It is designed for connections with remote locations where a "small code footprint" is required or the network bandwidth is limited. The publish-subscribe messaging pattern requires a message broker.
Andy Stanford-Clark of IBM and Arlen Nipper of Cirrus Link authored the first version of the protocol in 1999.[3]
The specification does not specify the meaning of "small code footprint" or the meaning of "limited network bandwidth". Thus, the protocol's availability for use depends on the context. In 2013, IBM submitted MQTT v3.1 to the OASIS specification body with a charter that ensured only minor changes to the specification could be accepted.[4] MQTT-SN[5] is a variation of the main protocol aimed at embedded devices on non-TCP/IP networks, such as ZigBee.
Historically, the "MQ" in "MQTT" came from IBM's MQ Series message queuing product line.[6] However, queuing itself is not required to be supported as a standard feature in all situations.[7]
Alternative protocols include the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP), Streaming Text Oriented Messaging Protocol (STOMP), the IETF Constrained Application Protocol,[8] XMPP,[9][10] DDS,[11] OPC UA,[12] and Web Application Messaging Protocol (WAMP). (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MQTT)

Das Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) ist ein zuverlässiges, verbindungsorientiertes Netzwerkprotokoll. Es gehört zur Transportschicht und setzt auf einem potenziell unzuverlässigen, verbindungslosen Paketdienst auf.

Es wurde von der Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) als neues Transportprotokoll vorgeschlagen und im Oktober 2000 in dem Standarddokument RFC 2960 veröffentlicht und im September 2007 durch RFC 4960 erweitert. Eine Einführung findet sich auch in RFC 3286. Das zuständige Gremium bei der IETF ist die Arbeitsgruppe Signaling Transport, kurz SIGTRAN.
Als Transportprotokoll steht SCTP auf derselben Stufe des TCP/IP-Referenzmodells wie TCP und UDP (Schicht 4 des OSI-Modells).
SCTP realisiert das Konzept einer Association: Hier wird eine Verbindung aufgebaut, in der mehrere Nachrichten-Datenströme in sich reihenfolgenerhaltend (untereinander aber potentiell nicht-reihenfolgenerhaltend) transportiert werden. Zusätzlich können einzelne, zum Beispiel dringende, Datagramme separat und außer der Reihe verschickt werden, die dadurch eventuell die In-Order-Datenströme „überholen“.
SCTP kennt außerdem Multistreaming und Multihoming (ein Host mit mehreren gültigen IP-Adressen). Es werden Heartbeats verwendet, um aktiv auf Verbindungsabriss zu testen.
Anders als TCP zeigt sich SCTP resistent gegen SYN-Flooding, eine Denial-of-Service-Attacke, bei der durch halboffene Verbindungen die Ressourcen des Servers aufgebraucht werden. Dazu verwendet es einen sogenannten Vier-Wege-Handshake. Hierbei speichert der Server bei einer Verbindungsanfrage (INIT-Paket) keine Zustandsinformationen, sondern schickt diese in Form eines Cookies (INIT-ACK-Paket) an den Client. Der Client muss dieses Cookie in seine Antwort (COOKIE-ECHO-Paket) einfügen und wird damit vom Server als zum Verbindungsaufbau berechtigt erkannt, was dieser ihm bestätigt (COOKIE-ACK-Paket). Ein ähnliches Verfahren ist mit TCP ebenfalls möglich, siehe SYN-Cookies.
Ursprünglich wurde SCTP als Transportprotokoll definiert, um Zeichengabenachrichten (SS7) aus Telefonnetzen auch über IP-Netzwerke übertragen zu können. Bei der Entwicklung stand insbesondere die Zuverlässigkeit des Protokolls im Vordergrund. SCTP ist aber auch für andere Anwendungen geeignet, da es Vorteile von TCP und UDP vereint. Eine wichtige, auf SCTP aufbauende Anwendung ist Reliable Server Pooling (RSerPool).
SCTP verwendet für Fluss- und Überlastkontrolle ähnliche Algorithmen wie TCP, verhält sich also in einem gemischten Netz (SCTP und TCP) neutral.[1]
Auch Java bietet seit Version 7 eine eigene API für SCTP an.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Infineon offers a family of angle sensors based on integrated Magneto Resistive (ixMR) technologies. Technologies include today iGMR and AMR. The sensors detect the orientation of an applied magnetic field by measuring sine and cosine angle components with monolithically integrated magneto resistive elements. ixMR technology is now widely used in automotive and industrial applications and provides a wide range of benefits. Our iAMR sensors are ideal for applications with the highest accuracy requirements. Our iAMR technology offers best performance over temperature, lifetime and magnetic field range. They are pre-calibrated and ready to use.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Training

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A work package is a group of related tasks within a project.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Work Package

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: All incoming pathways required to proceed along the flow All outgoing pathways must be followed Used to divide/rejoin tasks/flows which happen in parallel with another, rather than in a strict sequence
All outgoing process paths must be followed.
The connector is responsible for splitting the control flow in at least two different branches, which are executed parallely where all branches must be followed.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AND

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An application system type classifies individual application systems which have exactly the same technological properties. Process steps might be supported by application systems. Object describe IT systems (library for IT systems available).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Application system type

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Business Process consists of a series of value-creating activities that reach the performance expected by customers and fulfill goals derived from the business strategy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Business Process

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Business Process Activity is a part of a Business Process containing one or more sub Business Processes or a Process Flow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Business Process Activity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An EPC describes a Business Process Flow, which is a sequence of required tasks to create specified outputs using defined inputs. A Business Process Flow is a sequence of required tasks to create specified outputs using defined inputs.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Business Process Flow

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Business Process Landscape is a detailed overview of a specific Core- or Enabler Process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Business Process Landscape

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Physical equipment that makes up a computer system, such as circuit boards, keyboard and mouse, monitor, printer, power supply, storage devices. Contrasts with software.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Computer Hardware

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A connector determines the behavior of the process in case its control ?ow is split up into or joined from several execution branches.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Connector

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Denotes the event element that stands at the end of a branch in the process flow and thus, ends the process flow branch or the total process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: End Event

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Additional information to a process like work schedule, production plans, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Environmental Data

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An event illustrates the fact that a process object has taken on a business relevant state influencing the further procedure of a process. Unlike a function, which is a time consuming occurrence, an event is related to one point in time. Therefore, it is used to describe an event or status in the process flow. The object is mandatory for: EPC start and EPC end or after x (xor), v (or).

The event is a passive element since it represents a change of state but does not cause it. Furthermore it can characterize the conditions and the results of an activity, which in turn triggers the next function. An event with no incoming arc is called start event, while an event with no outgoing arc is called end event.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Event

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The function type represents several action elements as task, process interfaces or business process activities.

They are the active elements of an EPC that represent the activities of a modelled process and again raise events upon completion. The extended event driven process chain expands the semantic of functions, since they may be associated with the organizational unit performing the function or the data needed and created as output by the function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Function

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In IndustryPrint 5, function objects are used to model the decomposition of a process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Function Object

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Human being that puts effort in the processing of a process step (function). It belongs to the organizational unit that is responsible for the specific process step.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Human Output

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IPF is the structured overview of all IFX Core and Enabler Processes. It contains 4 Core Processes and 6 Enabler Processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Infineon Process Framework

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Item external to a system (such as a process) that is transformed by the system (usually together with one or more other items) to become an output.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Input

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rule element that unites the control flow after being split into several branches. Has several incoming paths (at least two) and one outgoing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Join Rule

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Semi or fully automated device that magnifies human physical and/or mental capabilities in performing one or more operations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Machine Resource

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The matter from which something can be made. Material can include but is not limited to raw and processed material, components, parts, assemblies, sub-assemblies, fuels, lubricants, coolants, cleaning agents, and small tools and accessories that may be consumed directly or indirectly.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Material

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: One striking commonality between EPC meta models is the Process. One process may contain an unlimited number of elements, but a process element is always linked to a specific process. If a process contains an interface, it is always linked to one specific process and represents a refinement of a normal function.
To graphically depict functional and process decomposition, function objects are diagramed on models in IndustryPrint 5.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Model

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An EPC model element is part of the EPC meta model and can be represented by a Function, an Event, an Operator, a Process Interface.
Represents an object in the EPC model. Includes all elements used in the modelling procedure of an EPC diagram.
Represents process flow elements except for modelling function objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Model Element
ModelElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Function objects are used to model the decomposition of the process flow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Modelling Function Object

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: At least one of the possible process paths must be followed.
It is responsible for splitting the control flow up in at least two different branches, due to an nonexclusive choice where one or several branches can be followed.

One or more incoming pathways required to proceed along the flow One or more outgoing pathways must be followed Used only when neither XOR nor AND can be used to better illustrate flow Has the weakest logic and should be used as sparingly as absolutely possible
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OR

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Collection of other services used as input to a production process or which are created during a production process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Other Services

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The amount of energy, work, goods, or services produced by a machine, factory, company, or an individual in a period.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Output

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A collection of subprocesses that meet a specific business objective. E.g. Perform Sourcing or Purchase Materials and Services
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The first level of process decomposition that is comprised of subprocesses that depict a business objective.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Diagram

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A set of a processes covering a single business area. Usually under the ownership of one business process owner and correlates to one module. E.g. Procurement
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Group

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A set of a processes covering a single business area. Usually under the ownership of one business process owner and aligning with a function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Group Map

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Process Interfaces connect several process models on the same Process hierarchical levelby linking the EPCs according to their shared events (also known as "horizontal navigation"). They thus facilitate process structuring and navigation by keeping models concise

Process interfaces connect several process models on the same process hierarchical level by linking the EPCs according to their shared events (also known as "horizontal navigation"). They thus facilitate process structuring and navigation by keeping models concise and easy-to-read. Functionality: Jump function to next process (e.g. EPC, VAC), typically at the end of process branches. In the EPC flow there is an Event directly before.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Interface

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A set of core and enabler processes of Infineon on Level 0 (highest level). This level helps helps organizing project work/ development and represents a single track in the oneSAP project. It is based on a Deloitte standard which was adapted to Infineon's needs.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Type

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A set of process types and related process groups that define the enterprise for a particular industry/sector.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Type Map

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Business Role (Person) that performs task.
Object to describe the role. Type of responsibility is defined by the linkage between function or activity and role. IFX options: carries out, contribute, must be informed.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Role

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rules allow to model alternative, exclusive alternative and parallel process flows.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Rule

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A transaction in SAP is described as a screen. Here, they represent the actions undertaken in the application SAP to perform a function in a process flow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Screen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rule element that splits the control flow into several branches. Has one incoming path and several (at least two) outgoing paths.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Split Rule

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Denotes the event that stands at the beginning of a branch in the process flow and thus, triggers the execution of this branch or the total process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Start Event

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Function objects are used to model the decomposition of the structure of a process.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Structural Function Object

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A grouping of related tasks that create an output within the larger objective of the subprocess. E.g. Create and Maintain Purchase Orders
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Subprocess

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The second and lowest level of process decomposition that is comprised of tasks that depict the role-based activities of the subprocess.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Subprocess Diagram

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Task is an instruction of a work package to create the output.
The lowest level of detail, a task are the activities required to execute a subprocess. A single task within a subprocess can be manual or system supported. E.g. Create Purchase Order
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Task

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Set up with connection to a function or activity or VAC. It can be either input or output, where the direction of the arrow describes whether it is an input or an output. Set up of a connection is not mandatory.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Technical Term

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Denotes the input element to a function in the process flow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Technical Term Input Element

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Denotes the output element of a function in the process flow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Technical Term Output Element

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Value-Added Chain is a process that represents an element of the process chain. A process hierarchy can be realized by hierarchically structuring value chains, thus modeling business areas, process groups, business processes and business process variants using the sam notation. House: represents enabler processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Value-added chain diagram

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Exactly one of the possible process paths must be followed.
It is responsible for splitting the control flow in at least two different branches, due to an exclusive choice where exactly one of the branches is followed.

One and only one of the incoming pathways is required to proceed along the flow One and only one of the outgoing pathways can be taken Divide should be made with yes/no question and lines labelled only with �yes� or �no� Gateway must therefore be named with this Yes/No question
owl:Class.rdfs:label: XOR

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Customer Part Number is the product identifier used by the customer to identify one IFX product.
In general, one CPN is equal to one Sales Product Name. Each customer will use a different CPN.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Customer Part Number Specification

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Die-Representative: supply element; where the package is not yet decided
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Die-Representative

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: NotReleasedProduct are those finishedProductNumbers that are not allowed to be shipped to any customer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plan Position: capacity and demand planning element

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ongoing Process of Entities (for the purposes of this ontology, mainly the Infineon device) deployed for a particular purpose. The deployment may have sub processes, such as installation, maintenance, addition, and decomissioning and removal.

Industrial sectors

The collection of all localized groups of enterprises that are producers of industrial commodities, in which each such group together forms the major industrial sector for the region. 'Industrial commodities' includes MechanicalDevices and basic industrial materials. Examples include 'the world industrial sector', the 'industrial sector of China'. The Chinese water pump industry would not be an exemplar of IndustrialEconomicSector but would rather be a sub-industry (see subIndustries) of it. On the other hand, chinese water pump manufacturers would be considered groupMembers of 'the industrial sector of China'.
This classification is done by The Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS) is an industry taxonomy developed in 1999 by MSCI and Standard & Poor's (S&P) for use by the global financial community. The GICS structure consists of 11 sectors, 24 industry groups, 68 industries and 157 sub-industries[1] into which S&P has categorized all major public companies

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The superclass of all classes describing products or services types, either by nature or purpose. Examples for such subclasses are "TV set", "vacuum cleaner", etc. An instance of this class can be either an actual product or service (gr:Individual), a placeholder instance for unknown instances of a mass-produced commodity (gr:SomeItems), or a model / prototype specification (gr:ProductOrServiceModel). When in doubt, use gr:SomeItems.
Examples: a) MyCellphone123, i.e. my personal, tangible cell phone (gr:Individual) b) Siemens1234, i.e. the Siemens cell phone make and model 1234 (gr:ProductOrServiceModel) c) dummyCellPhone123 as a placeholder for actual instances of a certain kind of cell phones (gr:SomeItems)
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: The Web Vocabulary for E-Commerce Good Relations http://www.heppnetz.de/ontologies/goodrelations/v1.html#ProductOrService

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any attribute of an entity

Any aspect of an Entity (but not a part of it), which cannot exist without that Entity. For example, the way the surface of a specific PhysicalObject looks like is a Quality, while the encoding of that Quality into e.g. a PhysicalAttribute should be modeled as a Region. From the design viewpoint, the Quality-Region distinction is useful only when individual aspects of an Entity are considered in a domain of discourse. For example, in an automotive context, it would be irrelevant to consider the aspects of car windows for a specific car, unless the factory wants to check a specific window against design parameters (anomaly detection). On the other hand, in an antiques context, the individual aspects for a specific piece of furniture are a major focus of attention, and may constitute the actual added value, because the design parameters for old furniture are often not fixed, and may not be viewed as 'anomalies'.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: World Wide Web Consortium SSN DUL https://www.w3.org/2005/Incubator/ssn/wiki/DUL_ssn#Quality

owl:Class.rdfs:label: SiC MOSFET

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A view, consistent with ('satisfying') a Description, on a set of entities. It can also be seen as a 'relational context' created by an observer on the basis of a 'frame' (i.e. a Description). For example, a PlanExecution is a context including some actions executed by agents according to certain parameters and expected tasks to be achieved from a Plan; a DiagnosedSituation is a context of observed entities that is interpreted on the basis of a Diagnosis, etc. Situation is also able to represent reified n-ary relations, where isSettingFor is the top-level relation for all binary projections of the n-ary relation. If used in a transformation pattern for n-ary relations, the designer should take care of creating only one subclass of Situation for each n-ary relation, otherwise the 'identification constraint' (Calvanese et al., IJCAI 2001) could be violated.
owl:Class.rdfs:isDefinedBy: World Wide Web Consortium SSN DUL https://www.w3.org/2005/Incubator/ssn/wiki/DUL_ssn#Situation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that proeprty was associated with.
Example: The activity of estimating the intensity of an earthquake using the Mercalli intensity scale is an Observation as is measuring the moment magnitude, i.e., the energy released by said earthquake.

Act of carrying out an (the method) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to an the methodProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that proeprty was associated with.
Example: The activity of estimating the intensity of an earthquake using the Mercalli intensity scale is an Observation as is measuring the moment magnitude, i.e., the energy released by said earthquake."
