owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Customer Logistics Management Representative is the “one face to our customers” that takes care of all customers’ supply chain topics. He or she channels all customer logistic requirements into Infineon’s organization and balances the needs against our capabilities.

Being the main interface between Customer, Sales and the Supply Chain Planner he is responsible for the demand fulfilment process. It is his task to ensure in-time delivery to customers based on orders and forecasts and to achieve high customer satisfaction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Customer Logistics Management Representative

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Order acknowledgement
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Confirmation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
Consignment Stock is a logistics concept where the supplier (Vendor) owned goods are stored at a customer location.
The supplier (Vendor) is responsible to maintain his stock within a defined min/max level.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ConsignmentOrders

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A person or entity that buys goods or services from a shop or business.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Customers

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A die bank is an area in production where (usually) tested wafers are stored waiting for disposition and further production.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DB

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A DC Facility represents a finished goods store.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DC

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The EDI Forecast Universe is a Data Mart that was started in 2010 (?) to support Forecast Accuracy analysis
owl:Class.rdfs:label: EDIForecast

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Forecast is an unconstrained prospect about the customer future demand.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Forecast

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The amount of inventory which should not be exceeded. The limit is normally determined after considering storage space of the facilities, how quickly inventory is sold or used, cost of insurance on inventory, and the risk of inventory becoming outdated before it is used.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MaxStock

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The minimum level of inventory is a kind of a precautionary level of inventory which indicates that the delivery of raw materials or merchandise may take more than the normal lead time.
The minimum level of stock is a certain predetermined minimum quantity of raw materials or product inventory which should always be available in stock in the normal course of business.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MinStock

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An order book is a business's list of open, unshipped, customer orders, normally time-phased and valued at actual individual order prices, that may include margin and profitability analysis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OpenOrderBook

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Every product on the order is referenced by a record that includes quantity and a reference to which order it belongs
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OrderLineItem

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any change in the requested order delivery date in an order line is referred to as an order rescheduling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OrdersReschedule

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is the uncommitted portion of supply by the master production schedule and material plan
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Promise

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resource capacity planning is about comparing future resource utilization of project resources against available capacity to do work.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ResourceCapacity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Describes a level of extra stock that is maintained to mitigate risk of stockouts caused by uncertainties in supply and demand.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SafetyStock

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A supply of something for use or sale
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Stocks

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: WIP includes the unfinished items for products in a production process. These items are not yet completed but either just being fabricated or waiting in a queue for further processing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: WIP

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Schedule lines contain all the delivery related information
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ordersScheduleLine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A capacity Bottleneck is defined as an equipment or multiple equipment that reflect the capacity of the whole line (either a dedicated Line or Pool sharing).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Bottlenecks

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As soon as a machine has free capacity: 1. all lots which belong to a priority class have to be dispatched imediately accordung to their priority rank.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Capacity

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The chemical polishing process or chemical mechanical planarization (CMP) is a process whereby a chemical reaction increases the mechanical removal rate of a material. CMP is commonly used to polish off high spots on wafers or films deposited on wafers, flattening the film or wafer, referred to as planarization. The chemical reaction that increases the mechanical removal rate is commonly tailored to provide a higher removal rate of one material versus another material. The chemical action in CMP helps to achieve higher selectivity's of one material to another than a strictly mechanical process would provide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Chemical Polishing

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: “Current WIP” entity describes the actual material distribution in the supply chain. (snapshot entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Current Work In Progress

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Cycle Time Commitment” entity helps controlling the WIP via the release plan. (strategy entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Cycle Time Commitment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The "Delivery Commitment" directly corresponds to the release plans and cycle time commitments introduced in the corresponding entities.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Delivery Commitment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Demand” entity stores redundant demand at every product level. (snapshot entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Demand Snapshot

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The deposition process, or chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is a process whereby a fiolm is deposited by reacting chemicals together in the gaseous or vapor phase to form a film. The gases or vapors utilized for CVD are compounds that contain the element to be deposited and that may be inducted to react with a substrate or other gas(es) to deposit a film. The CVD reactoin may be thermally activated, plasma induced, plasma enhanced CVD or activated by light in photon induced CVD.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Deposition

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: These lots have the same maxium waiting time as standard lots, however they are put before the standard lots.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Development

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Diffusion is a process whereby a substance redistributes from an area of relatively high concentration to an area of relatively low concentration due to random thermal motion. The larger the concentration gradient the faster diffusion occurs for a given temperature, conversely, the higher the temperature the faster diffusion occurs for a given concentration gradient.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Diffusion

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dry etching is a process whereby etching is accomplished by a reactive gas as opposed to a liquid. Dry etching techniques include plasma etch, reactive ion etch, magnetically enhanced reactive ion etch, inductively coupled plasma, electron spin resonance, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Dry Etching

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The EPA is a product identifier referring to the associated process.
The entity “Equipment” describes the semiconductor equipment of any equipment model. It allocates it to higher level entities and describes the behavior of the equipment. (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Equipment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Each machine is allocated to a group of machines doing similar processes. The equipment groups are described and allocated in the master entity “Equipment Group”. (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Equipment Group

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In the “Event Calendar” tracing entity, certain events like planned facility shutdowns, etc. can be scheduled
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Event Calendar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Fab” entity depicts the fab as a technological and physical production unit. (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Fabrication

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Each furnace consists of two chambers with one tool in each chamber.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Furnace

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sequence of interdependent and linked procedures which, at every stage, consume one or more resources (employee time, energy, machines, money) to convert inputs (data, material, parts, etc.) into outputs. These outputs then serve as inputs for the next stage until a known goal or end result is reached.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Furnace Process

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: These lots are processed after a certain maximum waiting time which is shorter than the maximum waiting time of standard lots. In general, for all classes, if there is more than one product type waiting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Hot

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Implantation or Ion Implantation is a technique where ions are accelerated to a higher energy and speed an injected into a semiconductor. The dominant techniques for introducing dopants into a semiconductor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Implantation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The lithography process is the key process in frontend. This consists of the following steps: a photo resisting layer is spun on a wafer, then exposed through the mask, then developed, then showing the effect on the open places, and then final deletion of the photo resisting material leaves only the remaining structure on the water. after some time for deposition, these steps are repeated up to 35 times.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lithography

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Lot represents manufacturing unit (e.g. in the semicondutor industry in Frontend this often consists of 25 or 50 wafers).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lot

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Lot Event” tracing entity gives the history of lot events. e.g. Hold events, Split events, Merge events, etc. (tracing entities)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lot Event

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A measure or quantity increment acceptable to or specified by the party offering to buy or sell. Used also as an alternative term for lot quantity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lot Size

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A transparent (glass or quartz) plate covered with an array of patterns used in making an IC. Each pattern consists of opaque and transparent areas that define the size and shape of all circuit and device elements. The mask is used to expose selected areas, and defines the areas to be processed. Masks may use emulsion, chrome, iron oxide, silicon or other material to produce the opaque areas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Mask

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A material transfer matrix estimates the duration of material from on to another equipment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Material Transfer Matrix

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The master entity “Operation” depicts the generic behavior of a single process step. Each operation has a foreign key relation to equipment and to route which means that the operation is required by the specific routes and requires a specific equipment. (workflow descriptive master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Operation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A user that interacts with the equipment only to the degree necessary for the equipment to perform its intended function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Operator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An owner is the entity that has the highest level of access authority or legal right to a system or equipment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Owner

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Semiconductor wafers arrive at the planning work center according to a Poisson process in lots with a certain unit size. The planning work center X48- can process three different products which arrive in four different classes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Planning Work Center

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Plant” entity describes the plant as a physical location of one or more fabs. The Plant belongs to a supply chain and can either be internal or external. (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Plant

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Each lot is characterized by a product type and a priority class. The priority classes are listed as follows: development, hot, productive, rocket and timecoupling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Priority Classes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sequence of interdependent and linked procedures which, at every stage, consume one or more resources (employee time, energy, machines, money) to convert inputs (data, material, parts, etc.) into outputs. These outputs then serve as inputs for the next stage until a known goal or end result is reached.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Process Class is the second hierarchy level in the Technology Catalogue and is a subset of top hierarchy level "Technology Class". A Process Class is defined by the device category and its generation or wafer diameter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Class

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: "A wafer technology is defined as a manufacturing process flow on wafer level including wafer test and pre-assembly which creates one device (discrete technology) or a set of different devices (IC technology) to be used in a product."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Flow

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Process Group is the third hierarchy level in the Technology Catalogue and a subset of the Process Class. A Process Group is defined by the device type and its generation (eventually voltage class) or wafer diameter
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Group

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Process Line is the forth hierarchy level in the Technology Catalogue and is a subset of Process Group. A Process Line is defined by WHAT is produced in detail
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Process Line

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A product is a work product that is delivered to the customer.
A product is any tangible output or service that is a result of a process and that is intended for delivery to a customer or end user.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: the product class is an entity used for planning and reporting. This helps create stable brand/name architectures to enable highest possible product portfolio transparency, true value creation ad to prevent from product TM overload.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Class

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A (main) product group is a grouping of products for calculation or sales purposes. The scope includes finished and unfinished products of one product line.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Group

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In the "product level" entity, the aggregation of elements enables the grouping of products and defines the relationship between products and groups at different hierarchy levels. This supports planning, logistics, modeling, forecasting and reporting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Level

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The product levels 3 to 1 are aggregated levels that are based on information from product level 4. (hierarchal aggregation level)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Level 2

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The static bottlenecks are determined in the “Product Level 3” master entity because the mid capacity planning is done on this first aggregated product level. There is no big difference in capacity from the aggregated level 3 product to its child level 4 products. (hierarchal aggregation level)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Level 3

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The product line is one of the most prominent grouping of products. It is used in reporting as well as for structuring organizations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Line

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The product number is a unique identifier of a product. The scope is limited to finished products only.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Product Number

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Production requests definte what the facilities need to produce when and in what quantity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Production Requests

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The standard lots, also referred to as Productive (Prod) lots, are the most common lot type and have no priority.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Productive

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: purge' is the application of an intert gas, or gas mixture, to the OD or ID surface of the weld joint to displace non-inert atmospheric gases. A block purge is a non-flowing purge with positive pressure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Purge

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The “Release Plan” entity shows the quantity planned to be released to a fab or facility. (strategy entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Release Plan

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The robot loads and unloads the lots from the WIP station into the furnace. Robot can load the furnace while another boat is processd by the tool.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Robot

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rocket lots are processed immediately if a machine has free capacity. The remaining furnace space is then filled up with lots of the same product.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Rocket

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The master entity “Route” describes the structure of a workflow out of operations. Every product uses a specific route in its value stream, i.e. the complete sequence of operations with all mandatory and optional operations necessary to complete the product. A route makes use of the single operations. (workflow descriptive master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Route

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Each workshop has a certain technical and operational workforce organized in shifts described in the “Shift” entity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Shift

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A simulation part helps to identify the same product in different locations. They are visible in Product Structures. This is a simulation entity and not a form of production/planning.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Simulation Part

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A simulation route (AKA workroute) represents a sequence of process steps in manufacutring (mainly at wafer fab). This is a simulation entity and not a form of production/planning.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Simulation Route

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The sputtering process, or physical vapor deposition (PVD) is the most used layering process today. Here gas atoms, mostly argon, strike out atoms from the cathode I an electric field which then form a thin film on the wafer surface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sputtering

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The entity “Supply Chain” describes the supply chain from the topmost level with all possible material flow edges, referring on the FabIDs (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Supply Chain

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The "target costs" entity is the final cost of a product or service that must be achieved in order to generate the desired level of sales revenue and income or due to contractual agreements.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Target Costs

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The target revenue is the amount of income a company wants to generate for the current accounting period.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Target Revenue

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The target service level is a performance indicator expressing the percentage of orders satisfied
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Target Service Level

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A semiconductor technology is a set of equipment, processes, manufacturing techniques and the related methods and procedures to enable the design & production of components, sub-components and modules.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Technology

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The tempering process is a type of heat treatment applied by the furnace. The process has the effect of toughening by lessing brittleness and reducing internal stresses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Tempering

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As single operations can set the lot to a time-critical state, time constraints can ensure that the operation setting it to an uncritical state is not delayed. Also the other case where certain time has to be spent between two operations can be covered with this master entity. (workflow deswcriptive master entities)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time Constraints

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lots of this type are requested by the next machine in the production line in irregular intervals. Special chemical characteristics require the lot being further processed immediately after the furnace operation. Thus, the downstram machines keep capacity free for the resulting time slot. timecoupling can be turned on or off. if it is on all lots are processed no matter how many are waiting and if not they wait.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time coupling

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A tool is any pieve of semiconductor fabrication or inspection equipment designed to process wafers. Often used synonymously with equipment in the silicon wafer processing industry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Tool

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Work in Progress (WIP) processing occurs here. WIP refers to the units of production that have been released into the factory, but have not yet been scrapped, have not been sent our for external rework, and have not finished processing through all of the production steps.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Work In Progress Station

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wet Etching is the process of removing material-etching, through the use of chemical activity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Wet Etching

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The overall organizational working structures within the fabs is described in the entity “Workshop”. (master entity)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Workshop

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
"The Agent class is the class of agents; things that do stuff. A well known sub-class is Person, representing people. Other kinds of agents include Organization and Group.
The Agent class is useful in a few places in FOAF where Person would have been overly specific. For example, the IM chat ID properties such as jabberID are typically associated with people, but sometimes belong to software bots."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Agent

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The foaf:Document class represents those things which are, broadly conceived, 'documents'
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Document

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Person class represents people. Something is a Person if it is a person. We don't nitpic about whether they're alive, dead, real, or imaginary. The Person class is a sub-class of the Agent class, since all people are considered 'agents' in FOAF.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Person
